awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Understanding Collagen Microcracks in Soft Tissues Under Normal Body Loads
awd_abstract_narration:
Researchers have extensively characterized sub-millimeter-scale fissures in osteoarthritis, but the PI's lab recently discovered that an impact usually considered non-injurious in fact causes micrometer-scale cracks in collagen of human cartilage. These microcracks may lead to pre-clinical osteoarthritis, but the extent to which they grow under repetitive loads during normal daily activities is unknown. This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award supports fundamental research to understand growth of collagen microcracks in soft tissues by validating novel computer simulations with new experimental data. Understanding and modeling cartilage microcracks will likely lead to new therapies and/or lifestyle modification strategies for osteoarthritis patients. Osteoarthritis afflicts nearly 20 percent of the US population; costs over $185.5BN a year (2007); and causes pain, functional limitations, lost earnings and depression, yet we understand neither its cause nor progression. The research will not only characterize one of the earliest observable signs of deterioration likely related to osteoarthritis, but also facilitate studies of other tissues and engineering materials. Moreover, this research will integrate education and outreach to promote interest in science among diverse underrepresented students. 

Leveraging cartilage as a model system, with availability of healthy and damaged human tissues and longitudinal magnetic reasonance images from the NIH-funded Osteoarthritis Initiative, this award will test the hypothesis that normal physiological loading causes existing cracks of a critical threshold size to propagate in the collagen network of cartilage. To quantify and predict origins of soft tissue damage propagation, the research team will quantify the micro-mechanics of cartilage's constituents; establish image-based, multi-scale simulations; predict microcrack propagation ex vivo; and test prediction sensitivity. Validation studies quantifying microcrack propagation ex vivo will confirm the predictive power of ex vivo and in vivo simulations. Next, the team will predict propagation of cartilage microcracks in vivo under physiological loads, e.g. running, using multi-scale simulations of full knee joints, and test whether areas with increased cartilage microcrack density collocate with cartilage thinning observed in early-stage osteoarthritis. The team will leverage every step to actively engage students. This award will provide: (1) baseline data on microcrack propagation; (2) validated tools to predict local micro-mechanics of damage in porous, fibrous materials from macroscopic deformations; (3) platform technologies to more broadly study mechanical function of fibrous load-bearing tissues (e.g. ligaments) and engineering materials; (4) mechanistic understanding of a likely path to osteoarthritis; (5) new markers to evaluate efficacy of therapies targeting early cartilage degeneration; (6) an educational platform to engage diverse students.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
Overview: We aimed to advance the mechanistic understanding of microcrack propagation in cartilage's collagen network by integrating new micro-mechanical experiments with a novel multi-scale modeling framework for fibrous, porous materials. We focused on predicting and quantifying the origins of damage propagation in cartilage and on integrating research with education and outreach to enhance student engagement.

Specialized Protocol for Type II Collagen Testing: While type I collagen mechanics are well documented, understanding of type II collagen fibers and networks remains limited. Our methods isolate and mechanically test type II collagen networks without altering measured mechanical parameters, advancing our understanding of tissue mechanics for therapeutic and tissue engineering applications.

Modeling Mechanics of Networked Type II Collagen: The stress-stretch and failure responses of networked type II collagen fibers are poorly defined. Through testing isolated collagen networks, we established constitutive models that accurately portray their mechanical behavior. These models elucidate type II collagen's role in mechanically loaded tissues like cartilage and intervertebral discs, enhancing predictions of tissue damage and degeneration.

Impact of Temperature on Cartilage Mechanics: We established how cartilage's mechanical responses to large-strain shear change across in vivo temperatures and supraphysiological thermal treatments. Results reveal temperature-dependent cartilage mechanics, with mechanical measures decreasing as temperature rises, informing potential treatments for damaged or osteoarthritic cartilage.

Multiscale Finite Element (FE) Method for Soft Tissue Mechanics: We developed a FE method for multi-scale mixtures (FE2M) to analyze soft tissues and fluid-saturated, porous engineered materials comprehensively. This framework offers insights into multi-scale mechanics, facilitating improved experimental analyses and benefiting researchers studying soft tissue biomechanics.

Quantifying Collagen Changes in Early Osteoarthritis (OA): Using TEM and custom image analyses, we quantified collagen-network changes in early osteoarthritic grades of human cartilage. Our findings highlight increased collagen fiber dispersion in the superficial and deep zones with early OA progression, aiding understanding of OA and potentially identifying biomarkers and treatments.

AI Model for Detecting Cartilage Microcracks: Our YOLO8 deep learning model identifies and segments microcracks in SHG images, enhancing detection accuracy and efficiency. Trained on 410 annotated images, this model supports timely OA management and encourages broader research accessibility through its public availability.

Tracking Microcracks in Cartilage Under Load: Investigating microcrack propagation in cartilage collagen networks under walking-induced cyclic compression, we found that low-energy impacts initiate and propagate microcracks. Understanding microcrack initiation informs therapeutic strategies for OA treatment.

Genipin Ineffective Against Cartilage Microcracks: Contrary to expectations, genipin treatments did not reduce cartilage microcrack initiation or propagation, suggesting limited effectiveness in enhancing cartilage resistance to microdamage.

Chondrocyte Responses to Low-Energy Impact: Chondrocytes respond to low-energy impact with both anabolic and catabolic effects, stimulating anabolic responses in the superficial zone and catabolic responses in the middle and deep zones of cartilage. This understanding informs treatments for cartilage-related diseases.

Democratizing Deep Learning for Cartilage Imaging: Our user-friendly CNN model accurately segments cartilage from MRIs, enabling precise clinical management and facilitating fundamental research without requiring specialized expertise or hardware.

Automated Hexahedral Meshing for Knee Cartilage: We established an automated method for hexahedral meshing of patient-specific knee structures from MRIs. This approach supports rapid, accurate mesh generation for testing hypotheses on disease progression, freely available for research and clinical applications.

Role of Finite Element Modeling: A review within our work underscores the significance of FE modeling in cartilage analyses. Our careful review lays the foundation for sophisticated models necessary to precisely capture the complexity of cartilage mechanics.

Incorporating Osmotic Prestretch in Cartilage Simulations: Integrating osmotic prestretch/prestress into cartilage simulations from medical images improves the fidelity of patient-specific biomechanical simulations, essential for accurately representing in vivo conditions and guiding clinical decisions.

Modeling Cartilage During Osteoarthritis Progression: Our computational models of cartilage and joints estimate intra-tissue stresses and evolving mechanical properties, crucial for understanding early OA stages and calibrating cartilage constitutive models to reflect OA severity.

Comparing Human Knee Mechanics with Cartilage Explants: Our results show explants estimate principal strains and maximum shear stresses well across diameters, but not principal stresses or interstitial fluid pressures. We clarified how ex vivo experiments relate to in vivo cartilage mechanics, aiming to reduce future studies in vivo.

Predictive Modeling of Cartilage Microcracks: Microcrack formation in the collagen network is critical to OA progression. Combining experimental findings with multiscale computational modeling validates accurate predictions of microcrack initiation and propagation, offering insights into OA pathogenesis and therapeutic strategies.

Impact Statement: Addressing the significant impact of OA on millions, our research aims to enhance public health through novel biomechanical tools that elucidate damage mechanisms, facilitating personalized, simulation-based predictive medicine for improved OA management and quality of life.

Workforce Development: Our team fosters skill development among PhD and post-doctoral researchers, advancing mechanical testing, theoretical mechanics, numerical modeling, and software development. Undergraduates engage in related research, contributing to understanding and preparing future researchers through educational outreach initiatives like UConn's da Vinci Workshops and the Joule Fellows Program.

 

 


Last Modified: 07/06/2024
Modified by: David M Pierce

Images (1 of )
  • a) We imaged fiber networks within the superficial zones of human articular cartilage using transmission electron microscopy. b) We quantified the orientation of fibers shown as a polar histogram. c) We verified the orientation parameters for each SERVE were statistically equivalent to experiment.
    Phoebe Szarek, David Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    Generation of statistically equivalent representative volume elements (SERVEs)
  • We generated SERVEs to model the network of type II collagen within cartilage with fibers (red, dark) aligned in the x-direction. We generated tetrahedral elements (translucent blue, light) filling the volume to represent the isotropic matrix, i.e. proteoglycan and fluid, within cartilage.
    Phoebe Szarek, David Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    Isometric view of statistically equivalent, representative volume elements (SERVEs) of collagen fiber networks from human cartilage.
  • (a) Average force-strain profiles of collagen type II molecule and (b) average hydrogen bond profiles at 24∘C, 40∘C, and 70∘C. Deformation states at (c) 24∘C, (d) 40∘C, and (e) 70∘C at six strains: (1) 0%, (2) 5%, (3) 12%, (4) 17%, (5) 23%, (6) 27%.
    Lauren Marshall, Anna Tarakanova, Phoebe Szarek, David Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    We observed two regimes in collagen deformation with the prescribed load: first, tensile unwinding, then shear slip as strand 3 slides along strands 1 and 2.
  • Representative SHG images of a control specimen (a-c) resting in PBS for the duration of the tests, and of two mechanically treated specimens (d-i) presenting microcracks: (d, g) pristine; (e, h) post impact at 2.5e4.0 mJ/mm3; and (f, i) post-cyclic compression at 10% and 15% respectively.
    S. Santos, N. Emery, C.P. Neu, D.M. Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    We co-registered second harmonic generation imaging (SHG) images for each specimen using relative coordinate mapping and feature matching.
  • Comparison of single-scale benchmark solution and the macrostructure of a two-scale FE2M solution for verification, results for fluid pressure: (a) p (single-scale benchmark) and (b) p (two-scale FE2M) and microscale (RVE) responses for elements 10, 410, 470, and 890.
    Ashkan Almasi, Tim Ricken, David M. Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    Validation using macroscopic results for both single-scale benchmark and two-scale FE2M simulations for fluid pressure p, for illustrative purposes we also show the microscale (RVE) responses for arbitrary elements 10, 410, 470, and 890.
  • (a) Segmentation of cartilages and menisci. (b) 3-D reconstruction of femoral (yellow) and tibial (blue) cartilages, medial (green) and lateral (red) menisci. (c) Corresponding mesh of 20-node hexahedral finite elements.
    B. Rodriguez-Vila, D. M. Pierce
    Copyrighted
    David M Pierce
    Patient-specific FE mesh established from baseline MR images from the OAI database.
